concepts.concept_name: Definition and effects of force
Types of forces: contact and non-contact
Pressure and its relation to force and area
Pressure exerted by liquids and gases
Atmospheric pressure

in_scope: Force as a push or pull
Effects of force: change in speed, direction, or shape
Contact forces: muscular, friction, normal
Non-contact forces: gravitational, magnetic, electrostatic
Pressure = Force / Area
SI unit of pressure: Pascal (Pa)
Factors affecting pressure: force and area
Pressure exerted by liquids increases with depth
Liquids exert equal pressure at the same depth
Atmospheric pressure and its evidence
Applications: sharp knives, wide tyres, dams thicker at bottom
out_of_scope: Newton's laws of motion — Introduced in Class 9
Pascal's law and hydraulic machines — Introduced in Class 9
Pressure calculations using P = ρgh — Introduced in Class 9

concepts.concept_name: Definition and causes of friction
Factors affecting friction
Types of friction: static, sliding, rolling
Advantages and disadvantages of friction
Methods to increase and reduce friction

in_scope: Friction opposes relative motion between surfaces
Caused by irregularities on surfaces in contact
Factors: nature of surfaces, weight of object
Static friction: opposes tendency to move
Sliding friction: opposes sliding motion
Rolling friction: opposes rolling motion
Static > Sliding > Rolling friction
Advantages: walking, writing, braking
Disadvantages: wear and tear, heat generation, energy loss
Increasing friction: treaded tyres, rough soles
Reducing friction: lubricants, ball bearings, polishing, streamlining
Fluid friction and streamlined shapes
out_of_scope: Coefficient of friction calculations — Introduced in Class 9
Laws of friction (Amontons' laws) — Introduced in Class 11
Angle of friction and repose — Introduced in Class 11

concepts.concept_name: Production and propagation of sound
Characteristics of sound: frequency, amplitude, time period
Loudness, pitch, and quality of sound
Audible and inaudible sounds: noise and music
Noise pollution: causes, effects, and prevention

in_scope: Sound is produced by vibrating objects
Sound needs a medium to travel (solid, liquid, gas)
Sound cannot travel through vacuum
Human voice box (larynx) produces sound
Frequency: number of oscillations per second (Hz)
Amplitude: maximum displacement from mean position
Time period: time for one complete oscillation
Loudness depends on amplitude
Pitch depends on frequency
Audible range: 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz
Noise vs music
Noise pollution: sources, harmful effects, measures to control
out_of_scope: Speed of sound calculations — Introduced in Class 9
Echo and reverberation — Introduced in Class 9
Ultrasound and infrasound applications — Introduced in Class 9

Chemical effects of electric current
Electroplating: process and applications
LED and tester for conductivity

in_scope: Good conductors and poor conductors of electricity
Some liquids conduct electricity (conducting solutions)
Distilled water does not conduct; salt/acid solutions do
Chemical effects: deposition of metal, bubbles, colour change
Electrolysis: basic concept
Electroplating: coating one metal with another using electric current
Applications of electroplating: chromium plating, silver/gold plating
LED tester to detect weak current flow
Identifying conducting and non-conducting liquids
out_of_scope: Ohm's law and resistance — Introduced in Class 10
Faraday's laws of electrolysis — Introduced in Class 12

Earthquakes: causes, effects, and safety measures

Two types of charges: positive and negative
Like charges repel, unlike charges attract
Transfer of charge between objects

Richter scale

Images formed by plane mirrors and characteristics
Multiple reflections and kaleidoscope

in_scope: Light travels in straight lines (rectilinear propagation)
Laws of reflection: angle of incidence = angle of reflection; incident ray, reflected ray, and normal lie in same plane
Regular reflection: smooth surfaces (plane mirror)
Diffused/irregular reflection: rough surfaces
Image formed by plane mirror: virtual, erect, laterally inverted, same size
Multiple images using two mirrors
Kaleidoscope: principle and construction
Sunlight is white light composed of seven colours (VIBGYOR)
Dispersion of light through a prism
Structure of human eye: cornea, iris, pupil, lens, retina
Braille system for visually impaired
Care of eyes
